If you mean Java, then this sounds astonishing. This could probably be tested pretty
easy by running code through an obfuscator, which moves all classes into the "default" 
package and renames every variable. One such obfuscator is Proguard (proguard.sf.net)
which we use in our projects.

Im VERY interested in the findings, since this would mean that if we need speed then we
should have variables and method names with 1 letter instead of good explaining names.


//Erik

PS. hmm, how does the JVM JIT compiler handle this? Do they keep the long names or
do they rename the vars? Maybe running without the JIT would solve this as well

  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Jim Dixon 
  To: junit@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Tuesday, September 23, 2003 10:37 PM
  Subject: Re: [junit] Re: Help plz...


  On Tue, 23 Sep 2003, ssmith12345uk wrote:

  Of course.  But one of the subthreads in this discussion is that
  comments can be made unnecessary by, for example, appropriate choice
  of variable/method/class/etc names.  This is something that we all do, I
  imagine.

  But the longer and more meaningful the names, the slower the code ;-)
